replies.author: @clivehorridge
replies.text:
@@minecraftfox4384

The F-16 was built under an unusual agreement creating a consortium between the United States and four NATO countries: Belgium, Denmark, the Netherlands and Norway. These countries jointly produced with the United States an initial 348 F-16s for their air forces. Final airframe assembly lines were located in Belgium and the Netherlands. The consortium's F-16s are assembled from components manufactured in all five countries. Belgium also provides final assembly of the F100 engine used in the European F-16s. Recently, Portugal joined the consortium. The long-term benefits of this program will be technology transfer among the nations producing the F-16, and a common-use aircraft for NATO nations. This program increases the supply and availability of repair parts in Europe and improves the F-16's combat readiness.

replies.author: @Clean97GTI
replies.text:
@@bekeneel Even the older F16s Ukraine is using can carry the AMRAAM-C. That's plenty dangerous for am SU-35 to face. Now, the Su-35 is a good aircraft and its modern radar and missiles help, but Russia isn't really flying them all that much. Air to air combat has been relatively rare in this war with Ukraine not really having the aircraft to attempt it, and Russia not wanting to lose expensive aircraft to western air defense missiles. 
Ukraine is using the F-16 and Mirage 2000-5 the right way, which is in ground attack roles. Neither side has air superiority and this has become a ground war. Ukraine is making decapitation strikes and has been starving the Russian war machine of ammo and oil/fuel. 
If Ukraine manages to get enough of a stockpile of guided bombs (from whatever country)

comments.text: I watched the aerial battle between Pakistan and India. I agree with what the Chinese said: if China supports Russia, then the Russia Ukraine war has already ended. Fortunately, China maintains neutrality between Russia and Ukraine. I believe the fundamental reason for China's neutrality is to maintain friendly relations with Europe. comments.author: @phongnguyen007
comments.text:
Watching Prof. Michael Clarke’s evolution over the course of the Ukraine war is like watching a seasoned analyst slowly morph into a motivational speaker for NATO. In the early days, he sounded grounded, cautious, and strategically aware — acknowledging the complexity of Russia’s military calculus. But somewhere along the way, perhaps after a few editorial meetings or a polite nudge from the Ministry of Narrative Control, he began to speak in a tone better suited for a pep rally than a geopolitical briefing.

Every Russian setback became ‘catastrophic,’ every Ukrainian gain ‘decisive,’ and every week was the 'turning point.' His analysis remained ‘based’ — in the technical sense — but strangely always tilted toward the most convenient optimism: Russia running out of missiles, China too afraid to move, NATO forever united, victory around the corner. It’s almost like he started fact-checking reality against Western morale, not the other way around.

There’s a quiet tragedy in seeing a once-serious voice reduce itself to a dispenser of feel-good predictions, just to keep the war-watchers comfortable. At this point, if Russia were to take Odesa, he’d probably say it's part of Ukraine’s master plan to lure them into overextension. It’s not analysis anymore — it’s theatre

replies.author: @JuhoJohansson-bz3jb
replies.text:
@@thewaywardwind548 well... sort of. The outcome might have been entirely different if they didn't have the western allies to support them... And their tactics were inefficient. For most part they were just sending poorly equipped soldiers, wave after wave, without much of an actual plan or strategy... Eventually Germany was defeated allright, but in reality what actually mattered came from the west. Soviet Union managed merely to sacrifice their own people for little gain.

While technically it does qualify as a win... In practice it takes a really messed up individual to celebrate such a sad chapter of history. Further compounded by the fact that what followed was Stalin's reign of oppression and terror. If you think the nazis were evil, you better think again, even cautious estimates would put the death toll of Stalin's regime far beyond whatever the nazis did, and this is excluding any actions of war... And Soviet Union didn't stop there.

So, to celebrate Soviet "victory" over the nazis... It is literally an exercise in bad taste, at best. It is practically about as smart as dancing on the graves of the innocent.

replies.author: @fuzed4324
replies.text:
​@@JuhoJohansson-bz3jb I'm not entirely sure if you realise that the Eastern front soaked up ~85% of Nazi troops. Without the USSR the west would have had zero chance of even successfully landing in Europe. Sure the lend-lease potentially played a critical role in the Eastern front, however, the allies on the West only landed in 1944, and by that time the Soviets were pushing back the Germans at a pretty rapid pace- on their own.

 In reality, it is estimated that out the ~27 million soviet casualties, 8~10 million deaths were actual military casualties. The rest were civilians which were rounded up and executed by German soldiers.

If you look at proper documentation and not random poor estimations, Stalin killed at a maximum of 2~3 million people. You can't compare him to Hitler, whose aim was to EXTERMINATE other races.

replies.author: @BinaryBlueBull
replies.text:
Nah, you're not "that guy"."That guy" is an annoying know-it-all, while what you did is simply share good info. Details matter in cases such as this. For instance, when Russian infantry comes across a Ukrainian IFV, they would be dead instantly when the airburst hits them. While, when they come across an APC, they might just (perhaps, maaaaaybe) survive a bit longer. Until the infantry dismounts that is, at which point they would be just as dead, though still a whole two minutes later than with the IFV. It's the same with the whole "rocket" versus "missile" thing. Small difference in wording, major difference in outcome, at least when you're talking about a wartime engagement

Details matter, so thank you for the correction, I knew of the difference between the two but just hadn't realized they had made a mistake

comments.author: @jeffalvich9434
comments.text: I and my wife both worked at Hughes Aircraft Company.  HAC designed and built the optical fire control systems for the Abrams series tanks and Bradley APC's.  FYI- the original Abrams Tank (A1M1) was actually designed and built by Chrysler Corporation- and they really did an incredible job!  The A1M2 was a significant upgrade designed to "work" in chemical warfare environments.  The avionic systems employed on these vehicles, I would not want to be on the receiving end, even with the Russian "best", our and the European allies would annihilate anything the Russians would have.

replies.author: @jamesvelvet3612
replies.text: I was an engineer at the Army Engine plant in Stratford, Connecticut where the AGT-1500 gas turbine in the Abrams was designed and manufactured.  Interesting fact:  The designer of the AGT-1500 also was instrumental in the first production turbine (found in the ME-206 of WW2).  He was allowed to enter the United States after the war along with other German scientists and engineers through Operation Paper Clip.

comments.author: @HermanKnippenberg-r4w
comments.text: The Kremlin, especially now before the parade on Red Square on May 9, ordered the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation, Sergei Lavrov, to remind about the topic of Nazism in Ukraine. It is the same as the equally absurd topic that the Russian Federation would give up its sovereignty completely to Romania and Poland. That is how it can be compared. The topic of Ukrainian Nazism is simply too marginal and insignificant to analyze at all, which means it is just wasted time. The real and fundamental reason for the Russian Federation to attack Ukraine in a warlike manner is that Ukraine, according to the Kremlin, must be under the thumb of the Moscow authorities, i.e. the Kremlin, and this is the "FUNDAMENTAL" reason for this war. And the fact that the Kremlin has once again commissioned Sergei Lavrov to speak, write and remind us of something so marginally, almost imperceptible, is as if the Kremlin had stated that the sun is cold at night because it is night and it is cold at night, or that it is definitely cold on the other side of the sun because we do not see it and we do not know the temperature on the other side of the sun, which is why the sun at night and on the other side of the sun must definitely be cold!!!!!! Because the Kremlin could have stated that it is so, and since "for example" something was said on Moscow television about the other part of the sun being definitely cold, it must definitely be so!!!!!! Not every Russian knows that what Moscow television says is true, but some believe it ;) Some Russians already know that this war cannot be won, which means they are dying unnecessarily. The Moscow media never tells the truth!!!!!! The Kremlin has been lying for 107 years, it does not matter what Sergei Lavrov says. It does not matter at all!!! Warmest regards! Hermann Knippenberg. comments.text:
Gotta admire the next-level dictatorship game here—running a country with an iron fist so well-polished it gleams like freedom. Bravo, Comrade Illusionist! Putin really nailed the “how to lose your future workforce in one war” strategy. Scare off the brains, send the broke to the front—classic empire-building, right?
Now we’re on track for the unlikeliest reboot: Russia, by Women—starring zero men under 60 and a population graph that looks like a ski slope. But hey, silver lining: the few surviving dudes can finally live their dream of being state-sponsored baby daddies. Romantic, really. Nothing says “thriving nation” like repopulating via grandpas and ghost towns.

comments.author: @HermanKnippenberg-r4w
comments.text: The Kremlin, especially now before the parade on Red Square on May 9, ordered the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Russian Federation, Sergei Lavrov, to remind about the topic of Nazism in Ukraine. It is the same as the equally absurd topic that the Russian Federation would give up its sovereignty completely to Romania and Poland. That is how it can be compared. The topic of Ukrainian Nazism is simply too marginal and insignificant to analyze at all, which means it is just wasted time. The real and fundamental reason for the Russian Federation to attack Ukraine in a warlike manner is that Ukraine, according to the Kremlin, must be under the thumb of the Moscow authorities, i.e. the Kremlin, and this is the "FUNDAMENTAL" reason for this war. And the fact that the Kremlin has once again commissioned Sergei Lavrov to speak, write and remind us of something so marginally, almost imperceptible, is as if the Kremlin had stated that the sun is cold at night because it is night and it is cold at night, or that it is definitely cold on the other side of the sun because we do not see it and we do not know the temperature on the other side of the sun, which is why the sun at night and on the other side of the sun must definitely be cold!!!!!! Because the Kremlin could have stated that it is so, and since "for example" something was said on Moscow television about the other part of the sun being definitely cold, it must definitely be so!!!!!! Not every Russian knows that what Moscow television says is true, but some believe it ;) Some Russians already know that this war cannot be won, which means they are dying unnecessarily. The Moscow media never tells the truth!!!!!! The Kremlin has been lying for 107 years, it does not matter what Sergei Lavrov says. It does not matter at all!!! Warmest regards! H. K.

comments.author: @AkinokazeHaruichiban
comments.text:
I really don't see how anyone [other than Putin and his bots] could possibly claim that Ukraine receiving defensive systems hurts the peace process.

The better defended Ukraine is, the fewer civilian casualties there will be and the fewer cards Russia has to play. At worst, this could lead to a stalemate, where Russia cannot take any further land, but Ukraine doesn't have the strength to retake any [though at current estimates, Russia is almost out of tanks and artillery, so may not even have the strength to hold onto the land they have stolen.]

comments.author: @cashaeleatemla
comments.text:
Ukrainian drones attacked Moscow for the second consecutive night, temporarily halting flights at four airports in the Russian capital and nine further afield – as it prepares to host a major military parade expected to be attended by world leaders including China’s Xi Jinping.

Moscow Mayor Sergey Sobyanin said in a Telegram post Tuesday that at least 19 Ukrainian drones were destroyed on their approach to the capital overnight, one night after Russian air defenses shot down four drones near the city.

There were no immediate reports of serious damage or casualties, but debris from downed drones fell on a major highway, Sobyanin said. Flights were suspended as a safety precaution at four of the capital’s airports, according to Russian aviation authorities.

The devices launched at Moscow were among 105 Ukrainian drones intercepted across Russia overnight, Russia’s defense ministry said on Telegram Tuesday.

The latest Ukrainian attack on the Russian capital comes ahead of Xi’s expected arrival in Moscow on Wednesday for a three-day state visit, in which the Chinese leader will take part in Friday’s May 9 Victory Day celebrations, according to a Kremlin statement Sunday.

Brazil’s President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, Vietnam’s President To Lam and Belarussian leader Aleksandr Lukashenko are among 29 leaders expected to attend, according to Russian presidential aide Yuri Ushakov. North Korea will send an ambassador to Moscow – and India, Nicaragua and South Africa will be represented by high-level delegations, he said.

Victory Day is the most significant day in Russian President Vladimir Putin’s calendar, as he has long used it to rally public support and demonstrate the country’s military prowess.

Thousands of people are expected to line the streets of Moscow’s Red Square on Friday in an exhibition of patriotism marking the Soviet Union’s role in defeating Nazi Germany and commemorating the more than 25 million Soviet soldiers and civilians who died during World War II.

comments.text:
From an observer point of view, it is not unacceptable if Putin does not want to sign the 30-day ceasefire. First, he wants to have clear terms in the ceasefire deal. Second, Russia has the upper hand since they have pushed most of Zelensky's soldiers out of Russia. Therefore, why does he need to sign? Thirdly, it is more from the point of view of a Vietnamese, Zelensky's situation is a lot similar to the situation of Nguyen Van Thieu, the president of Saigon Regime back in the VIetnamese resistance against the US since Thieu and Zelensky do not have any power to decide their fate. Well, I believe that's the cost of not having a sensible foreign and domestic policy =.=. 
The question is why are BBC and other Western media outlets trying to conclude that Russia was entirely wrong when discarding the ceasefire. It is true that they did invade Ukraine , but don't you think Zelensky and his malfunctioned government also contributed to their own demise?

comments.author: @rabmcnair4488
comments.text:
I am not an expert in intelligence or foreign policy. However, I can tell you the moment I realised that Russia would invade Ukraine: it was when Russia had made clear—repeatedly and emphatically—that Ukraine joining NATO was a red line, yet the United States continued to ignore these warnings. This, coupled with the events of 2014, which many view as a Western-backed coup in Kyiv, signalled a turning point.

When Alastair Campbell claims that the UK is not at war with Russia, he is either mistaken or being disingenuous. It is now openly acknowledged by American officials that this is, in effect, a proxy war between NATO and Russia, with Ukraine acting as NATO’s proxy. The scale of Western involvement—through the provision of military hardware, intelligence, training, and economic aid—goes far beyond passive support. Western leaders have used increasingly escalatory rhetoric, reinforcing the idea that this is not merely a regional conflict, but a theatre in a broader geopolitical struggle.

Moreover, this scenario was not unforeseeable. The Rand Corporation, a prominent American think tank, produced documents years ago discussing strategies to provoke Russia and overextend its resources—Ukraine was a key part of that analysis. While these documents were presented as theoretical policy planning, they have proven eerily prescient.

This is not to justify Russia’s invasion, but to contextualise it. Understanding the geopolitical provocations and strategic calculations on all sides is essential if we want to move beyond simplistic narratives and towards a resolution.

comments.text:
"In fact, the Army never solved the problems of low-intensity
conflict or its political dimension. Thus, when the twin towers fell on
September 11, 2001, the stage was set for a slow-motion military disaster.
The apparent “cheap win” in Afghanistan through special operations
forces and airpower further validated transformers’ convictions that
technology could supplant numbers.86 The Army that invaded Iraq in
March 2003 was tragically ill-prepared for the character of warfare that
it ultimately faced. While the depleted Iraqi Army rapidly melted before
the advance of the vastly superior American Army, it did not disappear.
Instead, the Iraqi soldiers hid among the population, evading America’s
high-tech surveillance and precision strike capabilities. Once Saddam’s
regime was toppled, the Iraqi Army reemerged, not as a conventional
military threat but as an insurgency that severely challenged America’s
halting efforts to establish a new Iraqi government. 
Other adversaries also emerged, including Shia militias, Sunni extremists, and foreign
terrorist groups."
 US Army War College Quarterly, Parameters                          
 Mistakes are lessons learned, if not ignored.

comments.author: @tomv1217
comments.text:
The standard Western position on the Ukraine conflict typically follows this logic:
•  Sovereign states have the right to choose their own alliances.
•  NATO is a defensive alliance and poses no threat to others.
•  The concept of “spheres of influence” (where big countries dominate neighbors) is rejected.

However, this narrative often overlooks key historical context:
↪︎ Warnings from Experts: For over 25 years, leading strategists-including George Kennan, Henry Kissinger, John Mearsheimer, and others-warned that NATO expansion could provoke conflict with Russia.
↪︎ NATO Expansion: Between 1999 and 2009, NATO admitted 12 new members in three rounds, moving steadily eastward toward Russia’s borders.
↪︎ U.S. Policy Shifts: In 2002, the U.S. withdrew from the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. Throughout the 2000s and 2010s, the U.S. installed missile defense systems in Eastern Europe, including Aegis Ashore sites in Romania (2016) and Poland (2024).
↪︎ Putin’s Warnings: In his 2007 Munich Security Conference speech, President Putin called for a new, fair partnership with the West but strongly criticized NATO’s expansion and U.S. dominance.
↪︎ Military Presence: NATO increased its military activities and deployments in Eastern Europe, further heightening Russian security concerns.
↪︎ Ukraine and Georgia: Western efforts to bring these former Soviet republics into NATO were met with strong Russian opposition, which saw them as direct threats.
↪︎ 2013-2014 Ukraine Crisis: In late 2013, Ukraine’s president suspended an EU Association Agreement under Western pressure, sparking protests (Maidan), which led to his ouster in February 2014. Russia viewed this as a coup; the West called it a revolution.
↪︎ Crimea and Donbas: Russia annexed Crimea after a disputed referendum in March 2014. Pro-Russian unrest and referendums followed in Donbas, escalating the conflict.
↪︎ Minsk Agreements: Attempts to resolve the conflict (Minsk I & II, 2015–2022) ultimately failed. Later, Western leaders like Merkel and Hollande admitted that Minsk was used to buy time for Ukraine to strengthen its military.
↪︎ Western Military Aid: From 2014 to 2021, Western support for Ukraine grew from non-lethal aid to advanced weapons and intelligence, aligning Ukraine more closely with NATO.
↪︎ Casualties: Around 13,000 combatants and civilians were killed in the Donbas from 2014 to 2021, largely due to Ukrainian shelling.
↪ Rejected Security Proposals: In December 2021, Russia proposed halting NATO expansion and restructuring European security, but the U.S. and NATO rejected these proposals.
↪ Recognition and Invasion: Russia recognized the Donetsk and Luhansk People’s Republics as independent in February 2022 and launched its “special military operation” (SMO) in Ukraine, citing the UN Charter’s right to self-defense.
↪︎ Peace Talks Blocked: In March 2022, British PM Boris Johnson reportedly discouraged Ukraine from signing the Istanbul Protocol, which would have included Ukrainian neutrality and security guarantees.
↪︎ Further Annexations: Russia annexed four more Ukrainian regions (Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson, Zaporizhzhia) in September 2022.
↪︎ Deep U.S.-Ukraine Partnership: An April 2025 New York Times article revealed a secret, deeply integrated U.S.-Ukraine partnership from early 2022, including intelligence sharing and strategic planning led by U.S. generals-suggesting a more direct U.S.-Russia confrontation than previously acknowledged.

While the West frames its actions as supporting sovereignty and defensive alliances, the historical record shows a pattern of expansion and military buildup that many experts warned would provoke Russia. Ignoring this context makes Western arguments appear selective and incomplete.

comments.author: @AlexandreLollini
comments.text: On the Magura drone we can see two pylons usually for air to air missiles on a fighter jet but upside down. Those pylons usually have pusher systems, (a spring would not be enough in general it is gas or explosive system) to push away the ordinance, so just before the missile is ignited, the pusher system launches is vertically and probably strong enough to give is proper clearance for it to be able to fly away without first crashing into the sea. Those pushers are important on a fighter jet because it is those which avoid the bomb or missile tu be sucked in toward the jet itself by aerodynamic forces (with potential catastrophic outcome). This probably required a lot of work and experimentation in order to fine tune for reliable weapon firing in a completely different way. Very clever.

comments.author: @Krieghandt
comments.text: The AIM-9 has always had a ground launch ability, it was launched from an M113 platform called MIM-72A/M48 Chaparral  It can reach much farther than a manpad, but not as far as when launched from a fighter jet.  It also has a lethal back blast, and is quite heavy,  which is why the US moved to a Stinger based system

comments.author: @miguelgordillo7561
comments.text: The AIM-9 Sidewinder platform is a well-known short-range Infrared missile form-factor that has been continuously upgraded since its inception in the 1950s.   For the purpose of drone-boat defense, the operator doesn't worry about where it is fired from as long as the target is an incoming target within the static range (zero velocity) of the missile.

replies.author: @peter8393
replies.text: War is best fought when it is not fought at all - Sun Tzu. The Duke of Wellington defeated French generals by building huge defensive lines and then going out to fight with limited troops until he could wear them down. As he advanced he was using a train of carts, donkeys et. al to supply his lengthening lines of communication. You don't need logistics for a battle but you do for a campaign - let alone a war. As a more useful quote would say "Fail to plan and you plan to fail"! As I state in my main comment Russia lost the war within a few weeks of starting it because they got bogged down and not because of the logistics issue.

comments.author: @leeharrison2722
comments.text:
I obviously do not have the expertise of Hodges or Fox, but I am surprised they did not specifically address several issues that seem "front and center" to me:

1. The vaunted Russian offensive... where is it? The Russians are now taking a beating around both Pokrovsk and Toretsk, yet they continue suicide attacks AND are losing ground. Losing ≈ 1200 per day while going backward is no joke.  Was the intent that the forces that threw the Ukrainians back in Kursk would become a serious offensive? It's not happening. So.... ???

2. Putin's mobilization ... really? To be useful to Putin these conscripts must be induced or coerced into signing the contracts for combat in Ukraine... and then what does he have?  Nothing more than fresh meat.  Russia doesn't have the tanks, APCs, or much of the other supplies.  And these raw recruits can't be trained to be anything more than meat in time for this fighting season.    Looks to me like Putin's army is desperately close to collapse.  What is the counter-argument against that?

3. Ukraine's long-range drones are getting numerous and there is steady progress on enhanced capability.  How much of a beating can Russia take?

comments.author: @wkent02
comments.text: The F16s being sent to Ukraine are from the US's "Boneyard" (309th Aerospace Maintenance and Regeneration Group) in Tucson, Arizona. The Boneyard does a bit of storage of old planes that could be rearmed and re-equipped for usage, as well as storage of old aircraft to be used for parts. Ukraine is receiving a few of these so called "parts planes". In recent years, a ton of the planes and helicopters have been rebuilt and sent into action from this storage facility.

replies.author: @Korporaal1
replies.text:
Which makes sense when we keep in mind that the RNLAF F-16 MLUs that Ukraine received are electronically very much among the most advanced F-16s out there (qua avionics, sensor equipment, communication and data-links, and such), but that the airframes are getting a bit worn. The Dutch AF had to patch up spots on several airframes because the extra equipment and heavy use caused bits to wear out faster. 
None of that is a problem when extra parts are available. Which is what the AMARG bodies are for. 

Remember that the European training programmes for UkAF F-16s are not just for pilots: Plane captains, maintenance crews, logistics people and staffers are also trained.

comments.author: @MrKockabilly
comments.text:
Fun fact: A military parade usually only involves just 1% of a country's total troops. And these men who participates are chosen based on:
1) Height. Parade organizers would choose participants who would have about the same height for aesthetics;
2) Dispensability. Units would send those whose absence (parade rehearsals take time) has the least impact in their organizations, so more likely the poor performers; and
3) As a more or less full-time assignment. Authoritarian countries like Russia and North Korea are maintaining soldiers whose only main duties are to do the parades and become "professionals" in that department.

comments.author: @alanhart383
comments.text: Thanks again for another great update, Denys.  In America, most people feel it is strange for Trump to be proclaiming new "Victory Days" for the end of WWI and WWII.  Since 1868, the USA has celebrated Memorial Day on 30 May and now the fourth Monday in May.  This federal holiday originally was held to honor the Union soldiers who died in the American Civil War; now it honors all military personnel that have died serving in any of America's wars.  Since the end of WWI in 1918 and the signing of the treaty in 1919, the USA has celebrated Veterans Day on 11 November, the date of Versailles Armistice  This federal holiday honors all currently serving and past members of the military in both peace and war time.  So the USA has been commemorating the end of WWI for 105 years... why do we need to change the name to Victory Day to appease Trump's ego?  And why do we need a second holiday in May celebrating the end of the European War in 1945?  Does this mean we should have an end of the Pacific war Victory Day on 2 September when Japan surrendered in 1945?  And Trump doesn't know history, he claims the USA "did more" to win these world wars than any other country.  How do we measure "did more"?  In Allied military and civilian deaths, Belarus lost 25% of their prewar population, Poland 17%, Ukraine, 16.5 %, the rest of the USSR 15%, France 2%, UK 1% and the USA 0.5%.  So instead of celebrating a victory, we should be focusing on the sacrifices made by all of our military personnel on our traditional Memorial Day and Veterans Day.

comments.text: I've looked at the aircraft 'boneyard' in AZ from Google Earth quite a few times, and I never saw an airplane there that was wrapped up like that, or at all. All of the aircraft were entirely exposed to the dust-storms and everything else.  Some had their doors closed and shrouds over engines, but they were clearly being kept functional, just in case. Why would they so meticulously wrap up old scrap hulls to send to Ukraine? I think those 'spare parts' fuselages are in a bit better shape than we're being told. Good.

I think you are correct, Denys.  The important thing about the minerals deal is that it gives the Trump administration a reason to support Ukraine.  If billions in American capital go to industry in Ukraine, the USA has a strong incentive to protect that investment.  If the support happens, (almost) all else pales to insignificance.

I am sure that President Zelenskyy does not need me to advice caution in any deal with the White House.

I am an American, and I absolutely loathe the idea of holding a military parade in America.  That is beneath despicable.  We have already received the disgust and derision of every civilized country in the world, but a Soviet-style military parade would be an irrecoverable humiliation.

comments.author: @gwapod9885
comments.text: I was working on the Fiberoptic Guided Missile (FOG_M) project at AT&T Bell Labs over 40 years ago. We had low cost missiles that could travel over 30 miles while controlled by a human directly to the target. The biggest challenge was developing a fiber that could withstand the high speed unreeling without breaking. It was amazing watching the spool of fiber unreeling at high speed when the missile launched.

comments.author: @MaXwellFalstein
comments.text:
Stunning war journalism, Richard, Jamie and Oleksandr.

There are a few ways to defeat a fibre optic FPV drone:
1. Laser
2. Kinetic kill (drone or missile)
3. mmWave RF

Dragonfire is the most capable laser platform.
Anduril's kinetic kill ramming drones are the best option when looking. ateffectivness against drones, cost, re-usability, speed of backing ih the fight and cost.
UK MoD just tested our mmWave RF weapon which is capable of destroying 100 drones in a swarm. mmWave is not jamming the radios to force the drone to land; mmWave is frying the drone's electronics which is the vulnerable part of any drone whether it be fibre optic or RF.

One thing is they fo drones are slower and limited in weight. 

The thing is wire guided missiles have been around since the 60s and were used in the 73 Yom Kippur war.

It surprises me this war has not utilised these earlier.

replies.author: @saintsone7877
replies.text:
@@TheNopih Firstly, let's examine the facts. Russia annexed Crimea in 2014 so that is NOT a gain of the war which began in 2022. 
Secondly, most of the Donbass region has been under Russian control since 2014, again NOT as a result of the war which began in 2022.
Thirdly, Russia expected victory very quickly when they invaded Ukraine in 2022. Evidence: The paratroopers who attempted to capture Kyiv and failed miserably had their victory uniforms in their backpacks. You do NOT carry such a uniform unless you expect little to no resistance and fully expect an easy and quick victory.
Fourthly, the fact Russia has used mercenaries, prisoners, North Korean soldiers, and equipment from many allies shows just how depleted their own forces/equipment is.
Last but not least, the fact is that they have in 3+ years failed to capture much territory they did not already have troops occupying various areas before 2022 says the mission has been an abject failure.
YOU can attempt to dress it up as much as you like but since 2022 Russia has accomplished very little in Ukraine and most military observers would say Russia is indeed losing this war badly.

replies.author: @zbyh1980
replies.text:
Money. The people who sign these contracts are mostly poor, marginalized folks who couldn’t find their place in normal life, a lot of them are drifters, even alcoholics. At one point, the Russian government was offering 2,000,000 rubles just to sign up, that’s about $20,000. For someone in Russia, where the average monthly salary is around $500, that’s like handing them four years’ worth of wages upfront. It's hard to say no when you’ve got nothing and someone waves that kind of money in your face.

Add to that ignorance; many of them have no idea what’s really going on at the front. When they signed up, they genuinely believed they wouldn’t be sent into battle. One Ukrainian journalist has been documenting interviews with Russian POWs, and every single one of them says the same thing: they joined for the money. Plain and simple. They were broke. It’s a poor nation, and when you're down to your last ruble, even the devil’s deal can start to look like salvation.

comments.text: That covering over the transported F-16 fuselages is the "cocoon" used to protect airframes designated for use as salvage for replacement parts.  Even in the desert you don't want sand and dust storms to infiltrate the airframes.  Most all of the aircraft being used for "reserve" or even salvage have preservation coverings to mitigate deterioration and infiltration of foreign materials.  And on another matter, Roswell, NM has a boneyard of commercial aircraft.

comments.author: @lukephilip2388
comments.text: Guys amazing work as always.   Regarding the President.  Nothing that has happened is of a surprise to anybody who understands him.  Unlike previous administrations who could be accused of being natural 'anti-Russia', this one has given Putin a chance at diplomacy.  It may appear like the US has been banging it's head against a brick wall, but 50 years from now after WW3, post analysis, it can never be denied that the option to avoid escalation was there.  The President has been overly fair to Russia, without prejudice, and it is often overlooked how significant this will be when we revisit from hindsight.  Russia failed the test.  They had the opportunity to gain Crimea.  I suspect their greed will now result in them losing all territory.

replies.author: @SnorriTheLlama
replies.text: @@mutteringmaleThis thinking is probably not well applied to the ongoing attritional phase of the Ukraine-Russia conflict. Thanks to drone spotters to immediately correct firing. Also, most reports have artillery and drones as the largest current causes of casualties. It has been the effectiveness of drone spotters for artillery that means large concentrations of troops are no longer possible as they get destroyed by artillery. The solution to this is smaller dispersed units, but this is where FPV drones then dominate the cause of casualties.

replies.author: @arnesieper8332
replies.text:
just a quick correction: ukraine is working towards artillery superiority, not supremacy.
supremacy would mean that russia has no artillery systems left to even fire back with. superiority means ukraine can fire more (and more accurate) than russia.

and, even after the GRAU deposit explosions and with the CZ-ammo program, for now artillery overall is roughly even. with how the russian push-system works, it will be probably two more weeks until the russian crews really feels the GRAU-incident. 

time will tell how (and from where) russia can acquisition artillery shells to make up for this loss.
if they cant, they will have 2 or 3 harsh months ahead, until restricted supplies will have cought up with production and things are back to normal for russian artillery.
dont get me wrong, that time is important, valuable and damn great for ukraine, but neitehr will it mean russia has no artillery left nor that they cant recouperate from it over a few months.
mistaking this for a "ukraine suddenly has superiority" is both wrong and dangerous for ukraine, because it could lead to careless decisionmaking.

comments.author: @r.a.dalton8807
comments.text: I am a 70 year old retired U.S. Army Master Sergeant (E8/1972-1993) and former defense contractor worker bee (2005-2010) who spent much of his career in the cold war. What we currently have in Ukraine is similar to the situation that existed for most of WWI on the west front: a stalemate with small gains won or lost by either side from day-to-day. Ukraine simply does not have enough equipment, forces or resources to take back the land they lost in 2022. On the flip side Russia no longer possesses the conventional forces needed to win the war on their terms as long as NATO nations continue to provide equipment and supplies to Ukraine. As for the lost land, Ukraine must accept the ground reality that the land they have lost to Russia is gone forever, especially the Crimea. The only way that could ever change would be if NATO directly intervenes in the war and fights Russia. If that were to happen, we would quickly move to WWIII and most likely a large nuclear exchange, so realistically I don't see such NATO intervention happening, as the stakes are just too high. The question at this point is how much more destruction and death must occur before both sides finally accept the truth that the current situation on the ground is as good as it going to get, and both sides finally end the war?  While personally I don't like to see Russia end the war with Ukrainian land as their ill-gotten gains, the war with it's ever increasing death and destruction must end before it at some point spirals further out of control and we end up in WWIII.

comments.author: @Olodus
comments.text: Ukraine continues to have a hard fight ahead of them, but they absolutely isn't out of this fight. Russia is running low on almost everything. Ammo (they have to buy from NK), manpower (look at the raising of incentive money to join) and tanks (according to open source satellite image analysis a lot of their Soviet stockpiles will run out in 2025 at this rate and their military industry, while large, can't keep up with the current loss rate). Finally, the Russian economy is in shambles and it has only gotten worse with the collapsing oil price so far into 2025. If Ukraine can keep it up over 2025 (with European support and possibly some but limited US support) Russia might be out of the count. As I said, still a hard fight ahead. But they certainly have a quite good chance at sticking it out.

Le problème c'est que les gens ont la même mentalité qu'au début de la Seconde Guerre Mondiale. Heureusement, moins largement partagée, et on a un gouvernement qui a les c**illes de prendre position. De mon point de vue, c'est la seule chose positive des deux mandats de Macron. Mais je n'oublie pas qu'il était très impressionné par Trump, il n'y a pas si longtemps.
Trop de gens pensent encore "c'est loin de chez nous", "ils s'arrêteront là". On a vu comment le Troisième Reich a profité de cette mentalité. Et Putin est complètement dans un état d'esprit similaire. Moins il y aura de réaction, plus son expansion militaire s'amplifiera. Déjà qu'il a peu de considération pour la pression internationale.
Faire plus ? Je ne pense pas qu'on puisse faire beaucoup plus sans que ça dégénère en guerre totale. On ne peut pas envoyer de troupes, mais on pourrait étendre les formations militaires. On a encore plein de casernes, heureusement.
On pourrait surtout faciliter et accueillir plus de réfugiés

My current tablet has the same multitask compute power as my 2014 pc had (3570 vs 3700 points). So suddenly the 40 year old Russian fighter got an Avionics upgrade which putt it into the 2015's. Looking at the F-16 it's the same story, what a modern F-16 makes it dangerous is the Avionics upgrades but it is an 45 year old Fighter Plattform. Using an "ipad" as Upgrade Path is ingenious.
